Are you happy folks with what's going on in Paris and other French cities presently? Me not!! I see devilish American hand behind those latest disturbances of marginal elements mainly of Muslim origin. In 2005 when we faced those Muslim hatreds first l didn't tend to observe any American involvement in'em though such suspicions were voiced then. Now I don't doubt it any more. 
 That is not just Muslim violence but rather a try to put into reality one more "orange revolution" scenario in Europe. That makes me really indignant. So far those have been immature democratic countries of Eastern Europe, they imposed their will on. I guess the experience has turned to be an encouraging one for'em. Now Americans have dared to make a similar try in a key EU state!!
 Well, it's simple. Conservative Nicholas Sarcozy firmly set to sort it out with brazen Muslims here is not up to American liking at all. Their favorite in the presidential race has been Segolene Royal 'cause she's not going to create any hurdles on the way of further strengthening of Muslim element in France.
 Well, there's same story even with next-to-skin American ally, Turkey, where Americans were not satisfied with the presidential elections results. There they were against Islamic strong advocate to occupy the presidential chair. I am absolutely sure the Turks owe the present mess in their country to Bush + Condy & Co.
 Isn't that time to bring "orange revolution" to USA, guys? The world would be a much safer place to live in then.

Do you mean Pétain? emoticon_confused

 
 No; Jean-Marie le Pen is the leader of the fascist french Front National party. He is very unpopular amongst most of the french population but has a core following of very enthusiastic supporters; he won 17% of the first round of presidential elections in 2002, largely due to the apathy of the politically moderate population whose voting turnout was the lowest on record. However, this sparked a renewed interest in democracy in France when the people saw how easily apathy can lead to extremsists getting near the reins of power, and he was soundly defeated in the second round elections by Chirac.
 
 A lesson for all democracies I think.
